elements.content: This work presents the systematic investigation on the reactions of Cd(II) ions with various aromatic polycarboxylic acids in organic solvents under solvothermal conditions. By using salts such as LiNO3 or NH4NO3 as templates, eight new metal-polycarboxylate frameworks, namely, (Me2NH2)[CdLi(p-BDC)2]·CH3OH (1), (Me2NH2)2[Cd(p-BDC)2]·(Me2NH) (2), (Me2NH2)[CdLi(m-BDC)2] (3), (Me2NH2)[Cd(OH-m-HBDC)(OH-m-BDC)]·DMF·CH3OH·H2O (4), [Cd1.5Li(5-But-m-BDC)2(DMF)2] (5), (Me2NH2)[CdLi(OBA)2] (6), (Me2NH2)[CdLi(SDBA)2]·DMF·CH3OH (7), and (Me2NH2)[Cd3(H2O)3(OH)(SDBA)3] (8) (p-H2BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, m-H2BDC = 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate, OH-m-H2BDC = 5-hydroxy-1,3-benzenedicarboxylate, 5-But-m-H2BDC = 5-tert-Butyl-1,3-benzenedicarboxylate, H2OBA = 4,4′-oxybis(benzoic acid) and H2SDBA = 4,4′-sulfonyldibenzoic acid) have been isolated in good yields from the reactions of corresponding polycarboxylate ligands with Cd(II) ions in DMF (or DMAC) at 160 °C. Their structures were determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction analyses and further characterized by elemental analyses, IR spectra, and thermogravimetric analyses. Compounds 1, 2, 3, 5, and 6 are three-dimensional frameworks, of which 1 features an unprecedented 6-connected topological network, while 2 and 3 have structures with qtz and pcu topologies, respectively. Both 4 and 7 have a two-dimensional layer framework, whereas 8 exhibits a one-dimensional chain structure. Compounds 1, 3, 6, and 7 are the first example of Cd(II)/Li(I) heterometallic coordination polymers, in which the Li(I) ions bond to carboxylate ligands and also are involved in the extending of polymer frameworks. All of these compounds except 1 and 5 crystallize in acentric (or chiral) space groups and the bulk materials for 3, 4, and 6 display strong powder second harmonic generation efficiencies, approximately 4, 2, and 5 times that of a potassium dihydrogen phosphate (KDP) powder. In addition, 4, 7, and 8 all have ferroelectric properties. The fluorescence properties and thermal stabilities for these compounds are also investigated.

elements.content: A series of cation-templated, polycarboxylate-based Cd(II) or Cd(II)/Li(I) frameworks have been synthesized in the presence of LiNO3 or NH4NO3 under solvothermal conditions. Compounds 1, 2, 3, 5, and 6 are three-dimensional frameworks, 4 and 7 are two-dimensional layer structures, and 8 exhibits a one-dimensional chain. Compound 1 features an unprecedented 6-connected topological network, while 2 and 3 show qtz and pcu topological networks, respectively. Compounds 3, 4, and 6 have second harmonic generation (SHG) efficiencies of about 4, 2, and 5 times that of a potassium dihydrogen phosphate (KDP) powder, respectively, and 8 exhibits a little weaker SHG efficiency compared to that of KDP. In addition, 4, 7, and 8 exhibit ferroelectric properties. The fluorescence properties and thermal stabilities for 1−8 are also investigated.
elements.clean_text: A series of cation-templated, polycarboxylate-based Cd(II) or Cd(II)/Li(I) frameworks have been synthesized in the presence of LiNO3 or NH4NO3 under solvothermal conditions. Compounds 1, 2, 3, 5, and 6 are three-dimensional frameworks, 4 and 7 are two-dimensional layer structures, and 8 exhibits a one-dimensional chain. Compound 1 features an unprecedented 6-connected topological network, while 2 and 3 show qtz and pcu topological networks, respectively. Compounds 3, 4, and 6 have second harmonic generation (SHG) efficiencies of about 4, 2, and 5 times that of a potassium dihydrogen phosphate (KDP) powder, respectively, and 8 exhibits a little weaker SHG efficiency compared to that of KDP. In addition, 4, 7, and 8 exhibit ferroelectric properties. The fluorescence properties and thermal stabilities for 1-8 are also investigated.

elements.content: The design and construction of metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) with unusual magnetic, second-order nonlinear optical (NLO), ferroelectric, photoluminescent, catalytic properties and gas adsorption are currently considered as one of the most important issues. In particular, NLO and ferroelectric behaviors are very useful and important physical properties in areas including ferroelectric random access memories, switchable NLO devices, optical communication, signal processing, and light modulators. Noncentrosymmetry (those lacking inversion symmetry) is an essential requirement for NLO materials, while ferroelectrisity strictly requires that the compounds must crystallize in noncentrosymmetric space groups belonging to one of 10 polar point groups (C 1, C 2, C s , C 2V , C 4, C 4V , C 3, C 3V , C 6, C 6V ). Therefore, the rational design and preparation of acentric or chiral networks are still a great challenge for synthetic chemists because most complexes are inclined to crystallize in a centric space group. Recent developments in the designed syntheses by self-assembly processes of metal-organic coordination polymers have afforded a variety of unusual topologies and functional materials with interesting properties. By the combination of appropriate metal ions with chiral ligands or using chiral metal complexes as structure-directing agents under mild conditions, acentric or chiral MOFs can be obtained, some of which display a strong NLO response or ferroelectric properties. Meanwhile, spontaneous chiral resolution by using achiral ligands provides another opportunity to prepare such NLO and ferroelectric materials. For example, Lin et al. has demonstrated that noncentrosymmetric networks can be achieved by using unsymmetric organic ligands (e.g., pyridinecarboxylates) in the combination with metal centers. Chen et al. also reported some chiral MOFs by employing unsymmetric ligands generated in situ under hydrothermal conditions. More recently, Cui et al. described a chiral octupolar three-dimensional (3D) metal−organic open framework of [(Me2NH2)2Cd3(C2O4)4]·MeOH·2H2O, generated from a simple achiral building block, showing a large NLO effect and cation-dependent NLO behavior.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design and construction of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with unusual magnetic, second-order nonlinear optical (NLO), ferroelectric, photoluminescent, catalytic properties and gas adsorption are currently considered as one of the most important issues. In particular, NLO and ferroelectric behaviors are very useful and important physical properties in areas including ferroelectric random access memories, switchable NLO devices, optical communication, signal processing, and light modulators. Noncentrosymmetry (those lacking inversion symmetry) is an essential requirement for NLO materials, while ferroelectrisity strictly requires that the compounds must crystallize in noncentrosymmetric space groups belonging to one of 10 polar point groups (C 1, C 2, C  s , C 2V , C 4, C 4V , C 3, C 3V , C 6, C 6V ). Therefore, the rational design and preparation of acentric or chiral networks are still a great challenge for synthetic chemists because most complexes are inclined to crystallize in a centric space group. Recent developments in the designed syntheses by self-assembly processes of metal-organic coordination polymers have afforded a variety of unusual topologies and functional materials with interesting properties. By the combination of appropriate metal ions with chiral ligands or using chiral metal complexes as structure-directing agents under mild conditions, acentric or chiral MOFs can be obtained, some of which display a strong NLO response or ferroelectric properties. Meanwhile, spontaneous chiral resolution by using achiral ligands provides another opportunity to prepare such NLO and ferroelectric materials. For example, Lin et al. has demonstrated that noncentrosymmetric networks can be achieved by using unsymmetric organic ligands (e.g., pyridinecarboxylates) in the combination with metal centers. Chen et al. also reported some chiral MOFs by employing unsymmetric ligands generated in situ under hydrothermal conditions. More recently, Cui et al. described a chiral octupolar three-dimensional (3D) metal-organic open framework of [(Me2NH2)2Cd3(C2O4)4]⋅MeOH⋅2H2O, generated from a simple achiral building block, showing a large NLO effect and cation-dependent NLO behavior.

elements.content: Although the use of unsymmetrical carboxylate ligands has been proven to be an effective approach for producing noncentrosymmetric or chial frameworks, in most cases, however, the formations of such frameworks are still unpredictable since there are many other factors, such as intramolecular interactions, solvents with different polarity, the type of templates used, and pH values which may influence the molecular organization in crystals. Therefore, more work needs to be done to explore the synthetic strategy of acentric MOFs.
elements.clean_text: Although the use of unsymmetrical carboxylate ligands has been proven to be an effective approach for producing noncentrosymmetric or chial frameworks, in most cases, however, the formations of such frameworks are still unpredictable since there are many other factors, such as intramolecular interactions, solvents with different polarity, the type of templates used, and pH values which may influence the molecular organization in crystals. Therefore, more work needs to be done to explore the synthetic strategy of acentric MOFs.

elements.content: Polycarboxylates have attracted attention in the synthesis of MOFs because of their versatile ligand types, diversity coordination modes with the metal ions, and sensitivity to pH values of the carboxylate groups. For a large number of metal-carboxylate frameworks reported so far, most of them are prepared in aqueous solutions or the mixture of water and organic solvents and very often some auxiliary chelate or bidentate N-donor ligands are introduced in the reaction system to promote the crystallization of the products. As a result, one (or two) coordination site of the metal center is usually occupied by a water molecule or a N-donor ligand. We intended to carry out similar reactions of carboxylate ligands with metal ions in organic solvents in the hope of making metal-carboxylate frameworks where the metal center was coordinated only by carboxylate oxygen atoms. In the reactions of Cd(II) ions with different polycarboxylic acids in DMF/methanol solutions at elevated temperature, it turned out that no crystals of the products could be isolated. However, in the presence of salts such as LiNO3 and NH4NO3, these reactions afforded several new Cd(II) and Cd(II)/Li(I) coordination frameworks, namely, (Me2NH2)[CdLi(p-BDC)2]·CH3OH (1), (Me2NH2)2[Cd(p-BDC)2]·Me2NH (2), (Me2NH2)[CdLi(m-BDC)2] (3), (Me2NH2)[Cd(OH-m-HBDC)(OH-m-BDC)]·DMF·CH3OH·H2O (4), [Cd1.5Li(5-But-m-BDC)2(DMF)2] (5), (Me2NH2)[CdLi(OBA)2] (6), (Me2NH2)[CdLi(SDBA)2]·DMF·CH3OH (7), and (Me2NH2)[Cd3(H2O)3(OH)(SDBA)3] (8) (p-H2BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate, m-H2BDC = 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate, OH-m-H2BDC = 5-hydroxy-1,3-benzenedicarboxylate, 5-But-m-H2BDC = 5-tert-butyl-1,3-benzenedicarboxylate, H2OBA = 4,4′-oxybis(benzoic acid) and H2SDBA = 4,4′-sulfonyldibenzoic acid, Chart ). Single crystal X-ray diffraction indicates that the Cd(II) ions in most of these compounds are eight-coordinated only by carboxylate oxygen atoms. Such coordination environment of the Cd(II) centers is very rare for the cadmium(II)-polycarboxylate MOFs. Except 1 and 5, the compounds isolated from these reactions crystallized in noncentrosymmetric (or chiral) space groups and compounds 3, 4, 6, and 8 have good second harmonic generation (SHG) activity. In addition, 4, 7, and 8 exhibit ferroelectric properties. All of these compounds present fluorescence properties and high thermal stabilities. According to our investigation, no reports on the MOFs with NLO or ferroelectric properties based on these polycarboxylates have been found with the exception of m-H2BDC.

elements.content: All the chemicals were commercially available and used as purchased. Thermogravimetric experiments were performed using a TGA/NETZSCH STA449C instrument heated from 30−800 °C (heating rate of 15 °C/min, nitrogen stream). IR spectra using KBr pellets were recorded on a Spectrum-One FT-IR spectrophotometer. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on crushed single crystals in the 2θ range 5−85° using Cu Kα radiation. The XRD of compounds 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 7 are measured on a PANalytical X’pert PRO X-ray diffractometer, and that of 6 and 8 are performed on a RIGAKU DMAX2500 X-ray diffractometer. The UV absorption spectra were measured at room temperature with a Perkin-Elmer Lambda 900 UV/vis spectrophotometer. A BaSO4 plate was used as a standard (100% reflectance). Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were determined using an Elementar Vario EL III elemental analyzer. Fluorescence spectra for the solid samples were performed on an Edinburgh Analytical instrument FLS920.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All the chemicals were commercially available and used as purchased. Thermogravimetric experiments were performed using a TGA/NETZSCH STA449C instrument heated from 30-800 °C (heating rate of 15 °C/min, nitrogen stream). IR spectra using KBr pellets were recorded on a Spectrum-One FT-IR spectrophotometer. The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on crushed single crystals in the 2θ range 5-85° using Cu Kα radiation. The XRD of compounds 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 7 are measured on a PANalytical X'pert PRO X-ray diffractometer, and that of 6 and 8 are performed on a RIGAKU DMAX2500 X-ray diffractometer. The UV absorption spectra were measured at room temperature with a Perkin-Elmer Lambda 900 UV/vis spectrophotometer. A BaSO4 plate was used as a standard (100% reflectance). Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were determined using an Elementar Vario EL III elemental analyzer. Fluorescence spectra for the solid samples were performed on an Edinburgh Analytical instrument FLS920.

elements.content: 0.5 mmol of Cd(NO3)2·4H2O, 1 mmol of p-H2BDC, and 0.5 mmol of LiNO3 were placed in a 20 mL of Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel with 10 mL of mixed-solvent of DMF (N,N-dimethylformamide) and methanol (V/V = 1:1). The mixture was heated to 160 °C in 4 h and kept to this temperature for 2 days. The reaction system was cooled slowly to room temperature during another 2 days. Colorless prismatic crystals of 1 were collected, washed thoroughly with DMF and CH3OH, and dried in air at room temperature (yield: 200 mg, 76% based on Cd(NO3)2·4H2O). Elemental analysis (%): calcd. for C19H20CdLiNO9 (525.71): C 43.41, H 3.83, N 2.66; found: C 43.68, H 4.01, N 2.70. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3427w, 3027w, 1575s, 1484s, 1447vw, 1392s, 1295w, 1151vw, 1090vw, 1012w, 950s, 890w, 837 m, 752s, 521s, 458vw.

elements.content: X-ray diffraction data were collected on a Rigaku diffractometer with a Mercury CCD area detector (Mo Kα; λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293(2) K. Empirical absorption corrections were applied to the data using the CrystalClear program. The structures were solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL-97 program. All the non-hydrogen atoms except those of the guest molecules in 4 and 7, the counterions of 7 and 8 and the μ3 -O atom in 8, were refined anisotropically. Some hydrogen atoms of the disordered counterions and guest molecules, as well as the benzene rings in 3 were not added. The other hydrogen atoms were either treated by geometrical positions or located from difference Fourier maps. Crystallographic data and other pertinent information for 1−8 are summarized in Table . Selected bond distances (Å) and angles (°) for these compounds are listed in . CCDC numbers for coordination polymers 1−8 are 733212−733219, respectively.

X-ray Crystallography

X-ray diffraction data were collected on a Rigaku diffractometer with a Mercury CCD area detector (Mo Kα; λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293(2) K. Empirical absorption corrections were applied to the data using the CrystalClear program. The structures were solved by the direct method and refined by the full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL-97 program. All the non-hydrogen atoms except those of the guest molecules in 4 and 7, the counterions of 7 and 8 and the μ3 -O atom in 8, were refined anisotropically. Some hydrogen atoms of the disordered counterions and guest molecules, as well as the benzene rings in 3 were not added. The other hydrogen atoms were either treated by geometrical positions or located from difference Fourier maps. Crystallographic data and other pertinent information for 1-8 are summarized in Table . Selected bond distances (Å) and angles (°) for these compounds are listed in . CCDC numbers for coordination polymers 1-8 are 733212-733219, respectively.

Hydrothermal or solvothermal synthesis has been proven to be a useful synthetic technique for the preparation of MOFs. The high temperature and pressure during these reactions can dramatically enhance the ligand solubility and the reactivity of reactants. With the aid of controlling the pH value of a solution and the temperature decreasing rate, as well as the appropriate choice of solvents and templates, crystallization of the products with different structural types can be achieved. For the preparation of metal-polycarboxylate MOFs, the solvents used are usually limited to water or the mixtures of water and organic solvents and in some cases auxiliary ligands are introduced to facilitate the crystallization of the products. However, what will happen to this reaction system when polycarboxylate ligands are utilized alone without adding a second ligand? To answer this question, we started our work on the reactions of Cd(II) with several different kinds of polycarboxylate ligands by using only organic solvents. In our initial investigation, alkalescent organic solvents such as DMF were employed, since they were considered to be able to automatically control the base/acid balance of the solution and at the same time provide cations such as (Me2NH2)+ at high temperature to either neutralize the overall charge in the solid or serve as a template. We found that the direct reactions of Cd(NO3)2·4H2O with a variety of polycarboxylic acids in DMF or the mixture of DMF and methanol at 160 °C yielded only a small amount of unidentified solid. However, by introducing LiNO3 (or NH4NO3 for 8, vide infra) to the reaction system, compounds 1−8 were isolated in good yields. Even in the cases where the Li(I) ion is not incorporated into the resulting complexes as in 2 and 4, its presence is still necessary for the formation of the products. This means that it not only serves as a framework-builder, but also functions as a template in the construction of these complexes. Similar reactions by replacement of LiNO3 with NH4NO3 gave no products aside from that between Cd(II) and H2SDBA from which (Me2NH2)[Cd3(H2O)3(μ3 -OH)(SDBA)3] (8) was isolated. The structure of 8 contains a μ3 -OH bridged tricadmium unit and clearly differs from that of 7 obtained from the analogous reaction with LiNO3. In addition, the choice of organic solvents is also crucial for the preparation of these compounds. For example, use of DMAC instead of DMF for these reactions only gave (Me2NH2)2[Cd(p-BDC)2]·Me2NH (2) as the sole product, whose structure is different from that of 1 isolated from the similar reaction with the same carboxylate ligand but in DMF/methanol solution. Single crystal X-ray diffraction indicates that the Li(I) ions in 1, 3, 6, and 7 also bond to carboxylate ligands, compensating the charge and, at the same time participate in nodes of dimensional grids. To the best of our knowledge, they present the first example of Cd(II)/Li(I) heterometallic coordination polymers.

Results and Discussion

Synthesis

Hydrothermal or solvothermal synthesis has been proven to be a useful synthetic technique for the preparation of MOFs. The high temperature and pressure during these reactions can dramatically enhance the ligand solubility and the reactivity of reactants. With the aid of controlling the pH value of a solution and the temperature decreasing rate, as well as the appropriate choice of solvents and templates, crystallization of the products with different structural types can be achieved. For the preparation of metal-polycarboxylate MOFs, the solvents used are usually limited to water or the mixtures of water and organic solvents and in some cases auxiliary ligands are introduced to facilitate the crystallization of the products. However, what will happen to this reaction system when polycarboxylate ligands are utilized alone without adding a second ligand? To answer this question, we started our work on the reactions of Cd(II) with several different kinds of polycarboxylate ligands by using only organic solvents. In our initial investigation, alkalescent organic solvents such as DMF were employed, since they were considered to be able to automatically control the base/acid balance of the solution and at the same time provide cations such as (Me2NH2)+ at high temperature to either neutralize the overall charge in the solid or serve as a template. We found that the direct reactions of Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O with a variety of polycarboxylic acids in DMF or the mixture of DMF and methanol at 160 °C yielded only a small amount of unidentified solid. However, by introducing LiNO3 (or NH4NO3 for 8, vide infra) to the reaction system, compounds 1-8 were isolated in good yields. Even in the cases where the Li(I) ion is not incorporated into the resulting complexes as in 2 and 4, its presence is still necessary for the formation of the products. This means that it not only serves as a framework-builder, but also functions as a template in the construction of these complexes. Similar reactions by replacement of LiNO3 with NH4NO3 gave no products aside from that between Cd(II) and H2SDBA from which (Me2NH2)[Cd3(H2O)3(μ3 -OH)(SDBA)3] (8) was isolated. The structure of 8 contains a μ3 -OH bridged tricadmium unit and clearly differs from that of 7 obtained from the analogous reaction with LiNO3. In addition, the choice of organic solvents is also crucial for the preparation of these compounds. For example, use of DMAC instead of DMF for these reactions only gave (Me2NH2)2[Cd(p-BDC)2]⋅Me2NH (2) as the sole product, whose structure is different from that of 1 isolated from the similar reaction with the same carboxylate ligand but in DMF/methanol solution. Single crystal X-ray diffraction indicates that the Li(I) ions in 1, 3, 6, and 7 also bond to carboxylate ligands, compensating the charge and, at the same time participate in nodes of dimensional grids. To the best of our knowledge, they present the first example of Cd(II)/Li(I) heterometallic coordination polymers.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that the asymmetric unit of 1 consists of half Cd(II) atom, half Li(I) atom, two half p-BDC2− ligands, half (Me2NH2)+ cation, and one guest CH3OH molecule. The cadmium(II) center is octa-coordinated, chelated by four carboxylate groups (O1, O2, O3, O4, O1A, O2A, O3A, and O4A), whereas the lithium(I) atom locates in a slightly distorted tetrahedral coordination environment which is made up from O2, O3, O2F, and O3F (Figure a). The p-BDC2− ligands, adopting a (k 2-μ2)-(k 2-μ2)-μ4 coordination mode, link the Cd(II) and Li(I) ions into a 3D anionic framework with large rhombic channels when viewed along the a axis (Figure b), which occupies 60.2% of the total crystal volume. The remaining space is occupied by CH3OH molecules and protonated dimethylamine counterions generated by the decomposition of DMF. The distances between the neighboring Cd(II) ions bridged by p-BDC2− dianions are 11.202 and 11.257 Å, respectively, and those at intervals of a Li(I) ion are 6.591 Å.

Description of Crystal Structures. (Me2NH2)[CdLi(p-BDC)2]⋅CH3OH (1)

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that the asymmetric unit of 1 consists of half Cd(II) atom, half Li(I) atom, two half p-BDC2- ligands, half (Me2NH2)+ cation, and one guest CH3OH molecule. The cadmium(II) center is octa-coordinated, chelated by four carboxylate groups (O1, O2, O3, O4, O1A, O2A, O3A, and O4A), whereas the lithium(I) atom locates in a slightly distorted tetrahedral coordination environment which is made up from O2, O3, O2F, and O3F (Figure a). The p-BDC2- ligands, adopting a (k 2-μ2)-(k 2-μ2)-μ4 coordination mode, link the Cd(II) and Li(I) ions into a 3D anionic framework with large rhombic channels when viewed along the a axis (Figure b), which occupies 60.2% of the total crystal volume. The remaining space is occupied by CH3OH molecules and protonated dimethylamine counterions generated by the decomposition of DMF. The distances between the neighboring Cd(II) ions bridged by p-BDC2- dianions are 11.202 and 11.257 Å, respectively, and those at intervals of a Li(I) ion are 6.591 Å.

elements.content: From the topological point of view, the p-BDC2− ligands and Cd−Li−Cd can be viewed as connectors and the Cd atoms as nodes (Figure a). Thus, the anionic framework can be abstracted into a 6-connected network (Figure c). The 3D topological network of 1 is analyzed by OLEX program, and the result shows that the Schläfli symbol can be described as (4867) and the vertex symbol of the Cd node is 4·4·4·4·4·4·4·4·62·62·62·62·62·62·720. Although topological nets with the Schläfli symbol (4867) are very common, according to our investigation, there is no one with the same vertex symbol as that of 1 reported so far. Therefore, the topological network of 1 offers another meritorious prototype of 6-connected nets that would be important for the design of the metal−organic coordination polymers.

Although topological nets with the Schläfli symbol (4867) are very common, according to our investigation, there is no one with the same vertex symbol as that of 1 reported so far. Therefore, the topological network of 1 offers another meritorious prototype of 6-connected nets that would be important for the design of the metal-organic coordination polymers.

elements.content: When the Li(I) ions in 1 are omitted, the 3D anionic framework become a triply self-interpenetrated distorted diamondoid topological network where the Cd−Cd−Cd angles range from 73.263 to 127.633°, showing a large distortion from the ideal tetrahedral angle of 109.5° found in diamond (). In fact, the Li(I) ion in 1 plays a role in extending the topological nodes from 4 to 6 and can be regarded as a bridge to link three diamond networks into a whole 3D framework. In addition, the Li(I) ion, together with a dimethylammonium cation, equalizes the charge of anionic network. The network structure of 1 closely resembles that of {[NMe2H2]2[Cd(p-BDC)2]·2DMF}∞. In this case, the charge of anionic network is balanced only by [NMe2H2]+ cations and the Cd(II) center is six-coordinated by oxygen atoms from four p-BDC2− ligands.

In addition, the Li(I) ion, together with a dimethylammonium cation, equalizes the charge of anionic network. The network structure of 1 closely resembles that of {[NMe2H2]2[Cd(p-BDC)2]⋅2DMF}∞. elements.content: The asymmetric unit of 2 contains one-quarter of Cd(II) ion, one-half of BDC2− ligand, one-half of (Me2NH2)+ counterion, and one-quarter of neutral Me2NH. Both the (Me2NH2)+ counterions and Me2NH moieties are derived from the decomposition of DMAC. The Cd(II) center is octa-coordinated, chelated by four carboxylate groups from different BDC2− ligands (Cd−O1 = 2.485(3) and Cd−O2 = 2.370(3) Å) (Figure a). The BDC2− ligands exhibit a (k 2)-(k 2)-μ2 coordination mode to link Cd(II) ions into a 3D anionic framework with large hexagonal channels when viewed along c axis (Figure b), which occupies 36.5% of the total crystal volume. The (Me2NH2)+ counterions and Me2NH molecules are located in the channels. The separation of the Cd···Cd atoms bridged by a p-BDC2− anion is 11.3509 Å.

(Me2NH2)2[Cd(p-BDC)2]⋅Me2NH (2)

The asymmetric unit of 2 contains one-quarter of Cd(II) ion, one-half of BDC2- ligand, one-half of (Me2NH2)+ counterion, and one-quarter of neutral Me2NH. Both the (Me2NH2)+ counterions and Me2NH moieties are derived from the decomposition of DMAC. The Cd(II) center is octa-coordinated, chelated by four carboxylate groups from different BDC2- ligands (Cd-O1 = 2.485(3) and Cd-O2 = 2.370(3) Å) (Figure a). The BDC2- ligands exhibit a (k 2)-(k 2)-μ2 coordination mode to link Cd(II) ions into a 3D anionic framework with large hexagonal channels when viewed along c axis (Figure b), which occupies 36.5% of the total crystal volume. The (Me2NH2)+ counterions and Me2NH molecules are located in the channels. The separation of the Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd atoms bridged by a p-BDC2- anion is 11.3509 Å.

elements.content: According to the simplification principle adopted in 1, the p-BDC2− ligands in 2 can be viewed as connectors and the Cd(II) ions in 2 are four-connected nodes. Therefore, the 3D anionic framework of 2 can be abstracted as a four-connected topological network with the Schläfli symbol and vertex symbol being (6482) and 6·6·62·62·87·87 analyzed by OLEX program, respectively (Figure c). According to O’Keeffe, this topological net with the Schläfli symbol (6482) is named as a qtz net. It should be pointed out that the structure of the anionic framework of 2 exhibits a 2-fold self-interpenetrated topological network, in which each six-membered ring of one net is catenated by four six-membered rings and two eight-membered rings from the other identical net, and each eight-membered ring of one net is catenated by two six-membered rings belonging to the other net ().

elements.content: Although a large number of p-H2BDC-based Cd(II) MOFs have been synthesized, most of them also contain terminal or bridging N-donor ligands. Those with only p-H2BDC ligands are rare. In fact, the only example of such complexes reported previously is {[NMe2H2]2[Cd(p-BDC)2]·2DMF}∞, whose structure is related to that of 2. However, there are significant structural differences between them. For example, {[NMe2H2]2[Cd(p-BDC)2]·2DMF}∞ has a triply interpenetrated diamondoid topological network where the Cd(II) ion is six-coordinated, being bonded to two k 1-carboxylates and two k 2-carboxylates of p-BDC2− dianions.

For example, {[NMe2H2]2[Cd(p-BDC)2]⋅2DMF}∞ has a triply interpenetrated diamondoid topological network where the Cd(II) ion is six-coordinated, being bonded to two k 1-carboxylates and two k 2-carboxylates of p-BDC2- dianions.

elements.content: In the asymmetric unit of 3, either the Cd(II) or Li(I) ion has only 1/8 site occupancy, and the whole carboxylate group has 1/2 site occupancy. The whole aromatic ring exhibits a striking positional disorder over two sites, which is quite common for a benzene ring. To our surprise, the (Me2NH2)+ cation in this structure cannot be located from the difference Fourier maps, as also observed in [In28Cd6S54]·[(CH3)4N]12[(HSCH2COOH)2]3.5, in which the (Me4N)+ cations and guest molecules could not be sought out. On the basis of microanalytical results, we speculate that there exists one (Me2NH2)+ cation per molecule in the crystal structure. The Cd(II) ion is octa-coordinated, chelated by four carboxylate groups (O1, O2, O1A, O2A, O1B, O2B, O1C, and O2C). The Li(I) ion is coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2, O2A, O2G, and O2H), resulting in a slightly deviated tetrahedral sphere (Figure a). The coordination environment of the Cd(II) and Li(I) ions, together with the coordination mode of the carboxylate ligands, are similar to those of 1. However, the Cd−O bond length (Cd1−O1 = 2.434(4) and Cd1−O2 = 2.369(7) Å) is less asymmetric compared to that observed in 1 (ranges from 2.3245(18) to 2.608(2) Å) and the Li−O bond distance (1.895(6)Å) is much shorter than that found for 1 (1.913(4) and 1.941(4) Å).

elements.content: The interconnections of m-BDC2− ligands and Cd(II), together with Li(I) ions, result in a 3D anionic framework with large square channels, which takes up 64.2% of the total crystal volume. The unfound (Me2NH2)+ cations are supposed to locate in the channels (Figure b). The distance between a Cd(II) and its symmetry-related atom bridged by the m-BDC2− ligand is 9.824 Å, while the separation of Cd···Cd at intervals of a Li(I) ion is 6.536 Å. The Li(I) ions in 3 not only function as linkers to extend the Cd(II)-carboxylate sheets into a 3D architecture but also balance the charge over the framework anion. Taking a similar analytical method employed in 1, the 3D anionic framework of 3 can be described as a six-connected topological network with the Schläfli symbol of (41263) (Figure c). The network can be specified by the vertex symbol of 4·4·4·4·4·4·4·4·4·4·4·4·*·*·* analyzed by OLEX program, which is a typical pcu topological network. On removing the Li(I) ions, the remaining anionic structure of 3 is a 2D layer network with (4, 4) topology (). Therefore, the pcu net of 3 can be viewed as being constructed by these 2D layers through the linkage of Cd−Li−Cd. According to our investigation, two m-H2BDC-based cadmium coordination polymers templated by dimethylammonium cations have been reported, namely, (Me2NH2)[CdNa(m-BDC)2] and (Me2NH2)2[Cd3(m-BDC)4]. In comparison with 3, they both crystallize in centrosymmetric space groups, and the Cd(II) ions in these two complexes are four- and six-coordinated, respectively.

elements.content: Compound 4 exhibits a 3D supramolecular framework arising from 2D layers extended by hydrogen bonds. The asymmetric unit of 4 is composed of one Cd(II) ion, one OH-m-HBDC− anion, one OH-m-BDC2− dianion, a (Me2NH2)+ cation as well as three guest molecules (one DMF, one CH3OH, and one H2O). The Cd1 ion is octa-coordinated by four chelating carboxylate groups (O1, O2, O5, O6, O3A, O4A, O7B, and O8B) from different carboxylate ligands (Cd−O 2.138(5)−2.685(7) Å), showing a distorted monocapped pentagonal bipyramid geometry (Figure a). It should be pointed out that the Cd1−O8B distance is 2.685(7) Å, which is more reasonable to be regarded as a semicoordination mode. Both the OH-m-HBDC− and OH-m-BDC2− ligands adopt a k 2-μ2 coordination mode, bridging between the Cd(II) ions and their symmetry-related atoms to form a 2D square grid, with the Cd···Cd distance bridged by a OH-BDC2− dianion being 10.133 Å (Figure b). The parallel 2D layers stack along the c-axis in a ABAB fashion to form a 3D supramolecular architecture via strong hydrogen-bond interactions between the phenolic hydroxyl (O9 and O10) and carboxylate oxygen atoms (O3 and O8) with the separation of O9−H23···O3i and O10−H24···O8ii being 2.724(8) and 2.659(9) Å, respectively [symmetry codes: (i) x, 1 − y, −0.5 + z; (ii) x, 1 − y, 0.5 + z]. The (Me2NH2)+ counterions and guest molecules are accommodated in the channels (). As far as know, coordination polymers constructed from Cd(II) and OH-m-H2BDC are relatively rare, most of which contain auxiliary N-donor ligands, such as bbp, bbip, and bimb, and none of them crystallizes in a noncentrosymmetric space group.

elements.content: As shown in Figure a, there exists one and half Cd(II) ions, one Li(I) ion, two 5-But-m-BDC2− dianions, and two coordinated DMF molecules in the asymmetric unit of 5. The crystallographically independent Cd1 and Cd2 ions have 1 and 1/2 site occupancies, respectively. The Cd1 center is hepta-coordinated, completed by three chelating carboxylate groups (O1, O2, O5, O6, O7B, and O8B) and one bidentate carboxylate oxygen atom (O3A), and its coordination geometry can be considered as monocapped pentagonal bipyramid. The Cd2 ion is hexa-coordinated and located in a slightly deviated octahedral sphere, with cis angles ranging between 89.301(85) and 90.699(85)°. The axial positions of this octahedron are occupied by two symmetry-related carboxylate O4 atoms (O4A and O4C), and the equatorial plane is defined by one carboxylate O1 atom and its symmetry-related atom (O1D), as well as two symmetry-related carboxylate O8 atoms (O8B and O8E). The Li(I) ion is in a distorted tetrahedral geometry, composed by two carboxylate atoms (O6 and O7B) and two DMF oxygen atoms (O9 and O10). The Cd−O (2.158(2)−2.604(3) Å) and Li−O (1.866(8)−1.975(7) Å) bond lengths are all within the normal ranges. The Cd2 lies on a 2-fold axis, which serves to generate eight-connected penta-metallic Cd3(O2CR)8Li2(DMF)4 secondary building units (SBUs) (Figure b). Within each Cd3(O2CR)8Li2(DMF)4 unit, the three Cd atoms are arranged in a linear configuration, with Cd···Cd···Cd angle of 180°and Cd···Cd distance of 3.387 Å. The Li···Cd···Cd angle in the SBU is 129.69°and the Li···Cd separation is 3.289 Å. There are two independent 5-But-m-BDC2− dianions which display (k 1-k 1)-(k 2-μ2)-μ4 and (k 2-μ2)-(k 2-μ3)-μ5 coordination modes, respectively (Figure a). The former cross-links the Cd3(O2CR)8Li2(DMF)4 SBUs into a chain along c-axis (Figure c), while the latter further connects these chains to form a 3D framework containing large rhombohedral channels filled with coordinated DMF molecules (Figure d). Within each pair of cross-linking 5-But-m-BDC2− ligands, there exist weak offset π···π interactions between the benzene rings with the centroid−centroid distance of 4.051 Å (). The Li(I) ions, terminally coordinated by two DMF molecules, are not involved in the extension of the framework. If the Li(I) ions and DMF molecules are omitted, a clear 3D anionic microporous framework could be obtained ().

elements.content: An interesting feature of 5 is that it contains a rare (k 2-μ2)-(k 2-μ3)-μ5 coordination fashion of the 5-But-m-BDC2− dianion which acts as a chelating-bridging tridentate/chelating-bridging tetradentate ligand to connect three Cd and two Li atoms. Dicarboxylate ligands with a (k 1-k 1)-(k 2-μ2)-μ4 coordination mode are frequently observed in MOFs; however, those with a (k 2-μ2)-(k 2-μ3)-μ5 mode as in 5 are rare and have only been seen in [Ni8(5-But-m-BDC)6(μ3-OH)4]. Another interesting feature is that an unique pentanuclear heterometallic Cd/Li SBU is found in 5, in which the three Cd(II) atoms (Cd1, Cd2, and Cd1D) are arranged in a line and a Li(I) ion is attached to each terminal Cd(II) atom. This SBU is somewhat similar to that observed in a 2D layer compound [Cd3(BDC)3(DMF)4]∞ (BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate). In this case, the Cd3 unit is six-coordinated by carboxylate ligands and unlike 5 where the DMF molecules are attached to the Li(I) atoms, the DMF molecules are directly bonded to terminal Cd(II) atoms, which prevents further extending of the Cd3 unit to a 3D structure.

elements.content: According to a search of structures from the CCDC, the coordination chemistry of the 5-But-m-H2BDC ligand is very rarely conducted, and no compounds with Cd(II) have been reported. Up to now, only three compounds of 5-But-m-H2BDC with molybdenum, zinc, and nickel metals, respectively, have been documented.

elements.content: In the asymmetric unit of 6, the site occupancies of Cd(II), Li(I), and (Me2NH2)+ are all 1/4, whereas that of OBA2− dianion is 1/2. The C atoms in the (Me2NH2)+ cation are positional disorder. As shown in Figure a, the Cd(II) ion is coordinated to four carboxylate groups [Cd−O 2.366(5)−2.477(3) Å], including O1, O2 and their symmetry-related atoms (O1A, O2A, O1B, O2B, O1C, and O2C). The Li(I) ion is embraced in a slightly deviated tetrahedron completed by O1 and its three symmetry-related atoms (O1C, O1G, and O1H) [Li1−O1 = 1.906(4) Å]. The OBA2− ligand adopts a (k 2-μ2)-(k 2-μ2)-μ4 coordination mode, linking Cd(II) and Li(I) ions into a 3D anionic architecture with large channels when viewed along the c axis (Figure b), which takes up 60.4% of the total crystal volume. The remaining space is inhabited by dimethylammonium counterions generated by the decomposition of DMF molecules. The distance of the adjacent Cd1 ions (Cd1···Cd1J) separated by a OBA2− ligand is 14.261 Å and that of Cd1···Cd1I at intervals of a Li(I) ion is 6.579 Å.

elements.content: Taking Cd1···Cd1J and Cd1···Cd1I as connectors and Cd1 ions as nodes, a 6-connected network equivalent to the 3D anionic framework of 6 is abstracted (Figure c). The 3D net was analyzed by OLEX program, which gave rise to the Schläfli symbol and vertex symbol of the Cd1 nodes as (4867) and 4·4·4·4·4·4·4·4·62·62·62·62·62·62·9140, respectively. It should be pointed out that there exists a precedent with the same topology reported by Schröder et al. If the Li(I) ions are likewise ignored, the 3D anionic framework of 6 can be abstracted as a typical diamondoid topological network with the Cd−Cd−Cd angles of 109.421 and 109.573°, being close to that of the perfect tetrahedral angle of 109.5°found in diamond. Furthermore, the Li(I)-omitted 3D anionic framework exhibits a 5-fold self-interpenetrated topological network where the six-membered ring of each diamondoid net is catenated by four six-membered rings of the other identical diamondoid networks (). Therefore, the overall framework of 6 can be considered as five interpenetrating diamondoid nets that are linked by Li(I) connections. For other known Cd/OBA coordination polymers, the flexible V-shaped OBA2− ligands usually result in helical chains, which are then connected by N-donor ligands to generate 2D layers. In one case, a 3D polymer has been formed as in [Cd(bpy)(OBA)] n . Thus, this kind of 3D structure constructed by Cd(II) ions and bridging OBA2− ligands as observed in 6 has not been reported so far.

If the Li(I) ions are likewise ignored, the 3D anionic framework of 6 can be abstracted as a typical diamondoid topological network with the Cd-Cd-Cd angles of 109.421 and 109.573°, being close to that of the perfect tetrahedral angle of 109.5°found in diamond. Furthermore, the Li(I)-omitted 3D anionic framework exhibits a 5-fold self-interpenetrated topological network where the six-membered ring of each diamondoid net is catenated by four six-membered rings of the other identical diamondoid networks (). Therefore, the overall framework of 6 can be considered as five interpenetrating diamondoid nets that are linked by Li(I) connections. For other known Cd/OBA coordination polymers, the flexible V-shaped OBA2- ligands usually result in helical chains, which are then connected by N-donor ligands to generate 2D layers. In one case, a 3D polymer has been formed as in [Cd(bpy)(OBA)] n . Thus, this kind of 3D structure constructed by Cd(II) ions and bridging OBA2- ligands as observed in 6 has not been reported so far.

elements.content: X-ray diffraction study shows that 7 has a 2D layer structure and its asymmetric unit contains one Cd(II) ion, one Li(I) ion, two SDBA2− dianions, one (Me2NH2)+ counterion, and two guest molecules (one DMF and one CH3OH). The Cd(II) ions is octa-coordinated, surrounded by four chelating carboxylate groups (O1, O2, O3, O4, O7, O8, O9, and O10) from four distinct SDBA2− ligands [Cd−O 2.343(14)−2.540(12) Å]. The coordination geometry of the Cd(II) ion in 7 can be considered as monocapped pentagonal bipyramidal and is different from other eight-coordinated Cd(II) ions which normally have a distorted square antipyramidal geometry. Another Cd(II)/SDBA complex with similar eight-coordinated Cd(II) center is [Cd(sfdb)(phen)2] n ·2nH2O, where four coordination sites of the Cd(II) ion are occupied by N atoms from two phen ligands. The Li(I) ion is located in a distorted tetrahedron sphere which is constituted by two carboxylate oxygen atoms (O8 and O10) and two symmetry-related oxygen atoms (O2D and O4D) [Li−O 1.80(3)−2.00(2) Å] (Figure a). The two SDBA2− ligands first link the Cd(II) ions into a 1D chain (Figure b). These 1D chains are further connected by the Li(I) ions to establish a 2D layer structure in which the SDBA2− dianion employs a (k 2-μ2)-(k 2-μ2)-μ4 coordination mode (Figure c). Such chelating-bridging bis(tridentate) coordination mode has not been observed for other metal-SDBA complexes. In fact, the incorporated Li(I) ion in this case acts as a connector to extend the dimension of the structure, and at the same time partly compensates the charge of the anionic network. The (Me2NH2)+ counterions are filled in the channels of the 2D layers, while the guest molecules (DMF and CH3OH) are located between the adjacent layers ().

elements.content: Compound 8 is a 1D chain structure and its asymmetric unit contains one Cd ion, one SDBA2− anion, one-third (μ3 -OH)−, one-third (Me2NH2)+ counterion, and one coordinated H2O molecule. Both the (μ3 -OH)− and (Me2NH2)+ are positional disordered with the site occupancies of O7, O7′, N1 and N1′ all being 1/6. The crystallographically independent Cd1 ion possesses the octahedral coordination environment whose axial positions are occupied by coordinated H2O molecules [Cd1−O8W = 2.333 (4) Å] and a (μ3 -OH)− oxygen atom [Cd1−O7 = 2.204(2) Å], whereas the equatorial plane is completed by four bidentate carboxylate oxygen atoms [O1, O2B, O5C and O6A, Cd−O, 2.317−2.319(4) Å] from four different SDBA2− dianions (Figure a). The Cd1 center is approximately coplanar with the mean plane of the four equatorial atoms with a deviation of 0.0009 Å. The SDBA2− ligand employs a (k 1-k 1)-(k 1-k 1)-μ4 coordination mode to connect the Cd1 ions into a 1D chain (Figure b). The most striking feature in the structure of 8 is the trinuclear Cd3(μ3 -OH) metal cluster, which is generated by the 3-fold rotational symmetry operation. A similar Cd3(μ3 -OH) core occurs in the octupolar 2D network [Cd3(μ3 -OH)L3(Py)6](ClO4)2 {L = 4-[2-(4-pyridyl)ethenyl]benzoate} reported by Lin et al. In a search of Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center (CCDC), it is found that the MOFs constructed from Cd2+ and H2SDBA have not been well explored. To date, only a few cadmium−organic frameworks containing H2SDBA ligand have been characterized. The coordination environments of the Cd(II) ions in most of these reported cadmium−organic frameworks are distorted octahedral geometries. In addition, unlike 7 and 8, all of them crystallize in centrosymmetric space groups.

elements.content: The powder X-ray diffraction patterns of compounds 1−8 are shown in with the pattern simulated on the basis of single crystal structures. The positions of the diffraction peaks in both patterns correspond well, which indicate that the as-synthesized samples 1−8 are pure. The IR spectra of 1−8 display characteristic absorption bands in the frequency range 1376−1663 cm−1 corresponding to νas(C−O) and νsym(C−O) of the carboxylate groups. The bands at around 3400 cm−1 are attributed to vibrations of N−H for (Me2NH2)+ cations and dimethylamine molecules []. The UV absorption spectra of 1−8 [] and the six free polycarboxylate ligands [] indicate that they are transparent above 360 nm. From 360 to 200 nm, the absorption increases quickly with the decreasing wavelength.
elements.clean_text:
Spectral and Thermal Characterizations

The powder X-ray diffraction patterns of compounds 1-8 are shown in  with the pattern simulated on the basis of single crystal structures. The positions of the diffraction peaks in both patterns correspond well, which indicate that the as-synthesized samples 1-8 are pure. The IR spectra of 1-8 display characteristic absorption bands in the frequency range 1376-1663 cm-1 corresponding to νas(C-O) and νsym(C-O) of the carboxylate groups. The bands at around 3400 cm-1 are attributed to vibrations of N-H for (Me2NH2)+ cations and dimethylamine molecules []. The UV absorption spectra of 1-8 [] and the six free polycarboxylate ligands [] indicate that they are transparent above 360 nm. From 360 to 200 nm, the absorption increases quickly with the decreasing wavelength.

elements.content: The thermal stability of 1−8 was examined by TGA in a nitrogen atmosphere []. The TGA curve of 1 indicates that there is a weight loss of 6.01% from 30 to 180 °C, which can be attributed to the loss of a CH3OH molecule (calcd = 6.09%). The second weight-loss step of 7.80% from 180 to 388 °C can be assigned to the loss of a Me2NH molecule (calcd = 8.56%). The residual composition of 1 is then decomposed from 388 °C. The TGA curve of 2 exhibits three main steps of weight losses. The first step is from 30 to 169 °C corresponding to the loss of a lattice Me2NH molecule (obsd = 7.92%, calcd = 7.79%). The second weight loss region occurs over the range of 169−350 °C relevant to the release of two Me2NH molecules (obsd = 16.84%, calcd = 15.58%). Above 350 °C the framework of 2 is decomposed gradually. For 3, the TGA curve shows that the Me2NH molecules are lost from 30 to 116 °C (obsd = 8.85%, calcd = 9.12%), and from 116 °C the framework of 2 was gradually decomposed. The TGA curve of 4 reveals that three kinds of guest molecules are gradually released from 30 to 255 °C (obsd = 20.18%, calcd = 19.13%), the successive weight-loss step could be corresponding to the release of a Me2NH molecule (obsd = 6.54%, calcd = 7.0%). Compound 5 is stable up to 120 °C, from which to 336 °C the two coordinated DMF molecules are lost (obsd = 19.35%, calcd = 19.16%). From 336 °C the framework of 5 begins to collapse. As for 6, it is stable up to about 264 °C, from which to 287 °C occurs the first weight-loss step corresponding to the release of a Me2NH molecule (obsd = 6.92%, calcd = 6.64%). For 7, the TGA curve indicates that the DMF and CH3OH guest molecules are lost from 30 to 265 °C (obsd = 11.67%, calcd = 11.94%), while the subsequent weight-loss step which spans from 265 to 286 °C corresponds to the loss of a Me2NH molecule (obsd = 4.83%, calcd = 5.12%). For 8, the three coordinated water molecules are lost from 30 to 322 °C (obsd = 4.01%, calcd = 3.95%), and from 322 °C the framework of 8 decomposed quickly.

elements.content: The second-order NLO properties of 2, 3, 4, 6, 7, and 8 were also investigated qualitatively based on the fact that these compounds all crystallize in acentric or chiral space groups (P6222, P4̅m2, Cc, I4̅2d, Cc, and P3, respectively). Approximate estimations were carried out on a pulsed Q-switched Nd:YAG laser at a wavelength of 1064 nm. The intensity of the green light (frequency-doubled output: λ = 532 nm) produced by the powder sample of 3, 4, and 6 are about 4, 2, and 5 times, respectively, of that produced by a potassium dihydrogen phosphate (KDP) powder. Compounds 2 and 7 were not detected obvious second-order NLO property, whereas 8 has a little weaker SHG effect compared to that of KDP.
elements.clean_text:
Second Harmonic Generation (SHG) Measurements

The second-order NLO properties of 2, 3, 4, 6, 7, and 8 were also investigated qualitatively based on the fact that these compounds all crystallize in acentric or chiral space groups (P6222, P4̅m2, Cc, I4̅2d, Cc, and P3, respectively). Approximate estimations were carried out on a pulsed Q-switched Nd:YAG laser at a wavelength of 1064 nm. The intensity of the green light (frequency-doubled output: λ = 532 nm) produced by the powder sample of 3, 4, and 6 are about 4, 2, and 5 times, respectively, of that produced by a potassium dihydrogen phosphate (KDP) powder. Compounds 2 and 7 were not detected obvious second-order NLO property, whereas 8 has a little weaker SHG effect compared to that of KDP.

elements.content: Compounds 4, 7, and 8 crystallize in noncentrosymmetric space groups (Cc, Cc, and P3, respectively), whose corresponding point groups fall in the 10 polar point groups (C 1, C s , C 2, C 2v , C 3, C 3v , C 4, C 4v , C 6, C 6v ) required for ferroelectric materials. Therefore, the ferroelectric properties of 4, 7, and 8 were examined. Experimental results indicate that they probably exhibit ferroelectric properties. Figure clearly shows that there is an electric hysteresis loop in 4 that is a typical feature for ferroelectric material with a remanent polarization (Pr) of ca. 0.0069 μC cm−2 and coercive field (Ec) of ca. 335 V cm−1. The saturation spontaneous polarization (Ps) of 4 is ca. 0.016 μC cm−2. Similarly, both the P−E curves of 7 and 8 also display an electric hysteresis loop that is characteristic of a ferroelectric material (Figures and ). The values of Pr, Ec and Ps can be estimated to be 0.0172 (for 7) and 0.0154 μC cm−2 (for 8), 592 (for 7) and 746 kV cm−1 (for 8) and 0.053 (for 7) and 0.041 μC cm−2 (for 8), respectively. We also studied the behavior of permittivity (ε) = ε1(ω) − iε 2(ω), where ε1(ω) and iε 2(ω) are the real (dielectric constant) and imaginary (dielectric loss) parts, respectively. As shown in , the respective frequency dependence of the dielectric constants ε1 of 4, 7, and 8 at room temperature (20 °C) indicate that their ε1 rapidly decrease with the increase of frequency. From 60 kHz (for 4), 25 kHz (for 7), and 12 kHz (for 8) to higher frequencies, their ε1 remains nearly unchanged.

The saturation spontaneous polarization (Ps) of 4 is ca. 0.016 μC cm-2. Similarly, both the P-E curves of 7 and 8 also display an electric hysteresis loop that is characteristic of a ferroelectric material (Figures  and ). The values of Pr, Ec and Ps can be estimated to be 0.0172 (for 7) and 0.0154 μC cm-2 (for 8), 592 (for 7) and 746 kV cm-1 (for 8) and 0.053 (for 7) and 0.041 μC cm-2 (for 8), respectively. We also studied the behavior of permittivity (ε) = ε1(ω) - iε 2(ω), where ε1(ω) and iε 2(ω) are the real (dielectric constant) and imaginary (dielectric loss) parts, respectively. elements.content: Recently, luminescent Zn(II) and Cd(II) coordination compounds have been intensively investigated for their interesting fluorescence properties and potential applications as new luminescent materials. For example, some zinc complexes have been reported to be used as organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs). In this work, luminescence properties of all compounds have been explored at room temperature in the solid state. Consequently, all complexes exhibit photoluminescence properties in the solid state []. As illustrated in Figure S15a−h, the intense emission bands at 433 nm (λex = 328 nm) for 1, 435 nm (λex = 328 nm) for 2, 424 nm (λex = 324 nm) for 3, 460 nm (λex = 350 nm) for 4, 424 nm (λex = 324 nm) for 5, 406 nm (λex = 304 nm) for 6, 438 nm (λex = 324 nm) for 7 and 439 nm (λex = 330 nm) for 8 are observed. According to the reported literature, the free p-H2BDC, m-H2BDC, OH-m-H2BDC, H2OBA, and H2SDBA ligands do not emit any luminescence in the range of 400−800 nm. In order to understand the nature of the emission band of 5, the photoluminescence property of the free 5-But-m-H2BDC ligand was also analyzed. It exhibits an emission band at 317 nm upon excitation at 280 nm []. Taking the emission bands of these free organic ligands into consideration, the emission bands of 1−8 may be assigned as intraligand π → π* excited states for Cd(II) has a d10 configuration and cannot readily accept π-electron density. The relatively low emission energies when compared with the uncomplexed carboxylic acids arise from changes in their electronic structures due to deprotonation and coordination to the Lewis acidic Cd(II). These coordination polymers may be excellent candidates for potential photoactive materials because they are highly thermally stable.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties

Recently, luminescent Zn(II) and Cd(II) coordination compounds have been intensively investigated for their interesting fluorescence properties and potential applications as new luminescent materials. For example, some zinc complexes have been reported to be used as organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs). In this work, luminescence properties of all compounds have been explored at room temperature in the solid state. Consequently, all complexes exhibit photoluminescence properties in the solid state []. As illustrated in Figure S15a-h, the intense emission bands at 433 nm (λex = 328 nm) for 1, 435 nm (λex = 328 nm) for 2, 424 nm (λex = 324 nm) for 3, 460 nm (λex = 350 nm) for 4, 424 nm (λex = 324 nm) for 5, 406 nm (λex = 304 nm) for 6, 438 nm (λex = 324 nm) for 7 and 439 nm (λex = 330 nm) for 8 are observed. According to the reported literature, the free p-H2BDC, m-H2BDC, OH-m-H2BDC, H2OBA, and H2SDBA ligands do not emit any luminescence in the range of 400-800 nm. In order to understand the nature of the emission band of 5, the photoluminescence property of the free 5-But-m-H2BDC ligand was also analyzed. It exhibits an emission band at 317 nm upon excitation at 280 nm []. Taking the emission bands of these free organic ligands into consideration, the emission bands of 1-8 may be assigned as intraligand π → π* excited states for Cd(II) has a d10 configuration and cannot readily accept π-electron density. The relatively low emission energies when compared with the uncomplexed carboxylic acids arise from changes in their electronic structures due to deprotonation and coordination to the Lewis acidic Cd(II). These coordination polymers may be excellent candidates for potential photoactive materials because they are highly thermally stable.

elements.content: On the basis of combination of Cd(II) ion and various of polycarboxylate ligands, several coordination polymer frameworks 1−8 were created with the aid of Li(I) or NH4 + cations. These polymers show some common feactures: (i) all of them with the exception of 1 and 5 crystallize in acentric (or chiral) space groups, (ii) except 5, the rests isolated from this reaction system are all anionic frameworks with counterions (Me2NH2)+ generated by the decomposition of DMF (DMAC in the case of 2), (iii) in the Cd(II)/Li(I) compounds, the Li(I) ions take part in the coordination to carboxylate ligands and serve as nodes of the anionic frameworks, and (iv) with the exclusion of 5 and 8, the Cd(II) ions all octa-coordinated by carboxylate groups, leaving no room for the coordinaion of water or solvent molecules. The geometry of these Cd(II) centers can be regarded as a monocapped pentagonal bypyramid. Eight-coordinated Cd(II) is not common, and those surrounded by only carboxylate oxygen atoms are extremely rare.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

On the basis of combination of Cd(II) ion and various of polycarboxylate ligands, several coordination polymer frameworks 1-8 were created with the aid of Li(I) or NH4 + cations. These polymers show some common feactures: (i) all of them with the exception of 1 and 5 crystallize in acentric (or chiral) space groups, (ii) except 5, the rests isolated from this reaction system are all anionic frameworks with counterions (Me2NH2)+ generated by the decomposition of DMF (DMAC in the case of 2), (iii) in the Cd(II)/Li(I) compounds, the Li(I) ions take part in the coordination to carboxylate ligands and serve as nodes of the anionic frameworks, and (iv) with the exclusion of 5 and 8, the Cd(II) ions all octa-coordinated by carboxylate groups, leaving no room for the coordinaion of water or solvent molecules. The geometry of these Cd(II) centers can be regarded as a monocapped pentagonal bypyramid. Eight-coordinated Cd(II) is not common, and those surrounded by only carboxylate oxygen atoms are extremely rare.

elements.content: In comparison with hydrothermal synthesis, reports on metal-polycarboxylate MOFs prepared by solvothermal synthesis is still sparse. Our work develops an alternative way to prepare new metal-polycarboxylate MOFs by using organic solvents in the combination of cations such as Li(I) and NH4 +. It may also provide an effective method to increase the chance for making nonsymmetry materials by using an achiral polycarboxylate ligand under appropriate conditions. The large SHG efficiencies of compounds such as 3 and 6, as well as their high thermal stabilities make them interesting for potential application in SHG materials. Further studies on the synthesis of related MOFs and their physical properties by making use of this synthetic method are already in progress.

elements.content: The powder second-harmonic generation test was carried out on the sample by the Kurtz and Perry method. Second-harmonic generation intensity data were obtained by placing a sieved (80−100 mesh) powder sample in an intense fundamental beam from a Q-switched Nd:YAG laser of wavelength 1064 nm. The output (λ = 532 nm) was filtered first to remove the multiplier and was then displayed on an oscilloscope. This procedure was then repeated using standard NLO material (microcrystalline KDP), and the ratio of the second-harmonic intensity outputs was calculated.

References

The powder second-harmonic generation test was carried out on the sample by the Kurtz and Perry method. Second-harmonic generation intensity data were obtained by placing a sieved (80-100 mesh) powder sample in an intense fundamental beam from a Q-switched Nd:YAG laser of wavelength 1064 nm. The output (λ = 532 nm) was filtered first to remove the multiplier and was then displayed on an oscilloscope. This procedure was then repeated using standard NLO material (microcrystalline KDP), and the ratio of the second-harmonic intensity outputs was calculated.

0.5 mmol of Cd(NO3)2·4H2O, 1 mmol of p-H2BDC, and 0.5 mmol of LiNO3 were placed in a 20 mL of Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel with 10 mL of mixed-solvent of DMF (N,N-dimethylformamide) and methanol (V/V = 1:1). The mixture was heated to 160 °C in 4 h and kept to this temperature for 2 days. The reaction system was cooled slowly to room temperature during another 2 days. Colorless prismatic crystals of 1 were collected, washed thoroughly with DMF and CH3OH, and dried in air at room temperature (yield: 200 mg, 76% based on Cd(NO3)2·4H2O). Elemental analysis (%): calcd. for C19H20CdLiNO9 (525.71): C 43.41, H 3.83, N 2.66; found: C 43.68, H 4.01, N 2.70. cln_elements.content:
The thermal stability of 1−8 was examined by TGA in a nitrogen atmosphere []. The TGA curve of 1 indicates that there is a weight loss of 6.01% from 30 to 180 °C, which can be attributed to the loss of a CH3OH molecule (calcd = 6.09%). The second weight-loss step of 7.80% from 180 to 388 °C can be assigned to the loss of a Me2NH molecule (calcd = 8.56%). The residual composition of 1 is then decomposed from 388 °C. The TGA curve of 2 exhibits three main steps of weight losses. The first step is from 30 to 169 °C corresponding to the loss of a lattice Me2NH molecule (obsd = 7.92%, calcd = 7.79%). The second weight loss region occurs over the range of 169−350 °C relevant to the release of two Me2NH molecules (obsd = 16.84%, calcd = 15.58%). Above 350 °C the framework of 2 is decomposed gradually. For 3, the TGA curve shows that the Me2NH molecules are lost from 30 to 116 °C (obsd = 8.85%, calcd = 9.12%), and from 116 °C the framework of 2 was gradually decomposed. The TGA curve of 4 reveals that three kinds of guest molecules are gradually released from 30 to 255 °C (obsd = 20.18%, calcd = 19.13%), the successive weight-loss step could be corresponding to the release of a Me2NH molecule (obsd = 6.54%, calcd = 7.0%). Compound 5 is stable up to 120 °C, from which to 336 °C the two coordinated DMF molecules are lost (obsd = 19.35%, calcd = 19.16%). From 336 °C the framework of 5 begins to collapse. As for 6, it is stable up to about 264 °C, from which to 287 °C occurs the first weight-loss step corresponding to the release of a Me2NH molecule (obsd = 6.92%, calcd = 6.64%). For 7, the TGA curve indicates that the DMF and CH3OH guest molecules are lost from 30 to 265 °C (obsd = 11.67%, calcd = 11.94%), while the subsequent weight-loss step which spans from 265 to 286 °C corresponds to the loss of a Me2NH molecule (obsd = 4.83%, calcd = 5.12%). For 8, the three coordinated water molecules are lost from 30 to 322 °C (obsd = 4.01%, calcd = 3.95%), and from 322 °C the framework of 8 decomposed quickly.

Ferroelectric Properties

Compounds 4, 7, and 8 crystallize in noncentrosymmetric space groups (Cc, Cc, and P3, respectively), whose corresponding point groups fall in the 10 polar point groups (C 1, C s , C 2, C 2v , C 3, C 3v , C 4, C 4v , C 6, C 6v ) required for ferroelectric materials. Therefore, the ferroelectric properties of 4, 7, and 8 were examined. Experimental results indicate that they probably exhibit ferroelectric properties. Figure clearly shows that there is an electric hysteresis loop in 4 that is a typical feature for ferroelectric material with a remanent polarization (Pr) of ca. 0.0069 μC cm−2 and coercive field (Ec) of ca. 335 V cm−1. The saturation spontaneous polarization (Ps) of 4 is ca. 0.016 μC cm−2. Similarly, both the P−E curves of 7 and 8 also display an electric hysteresis loop that is characteristic of a ferroelectric material (Figures and ). The values of Pr, Ec and Ps can be estimated to be 0.0172 (for 7) and 0.0154 μC cm−2 (for 8), 592 (for 7) and 746 kV cm−1 (for 8) and 0.053 (for 7) and 0.041 μC cm−2 (for 8), respectively. We also studied the behavior of permittivity (ε) = ε1(ω) − iε 2(ω), where ε1(ω) and iε 2(ω) are the real (dielectric constant) and imaginary (dielectric loss) parts, respectively. As shown in , the respective frequency dependence of the dielectric constants ε1 of 4, 7, and 8 at room temperature (20 °C) indicate that their ε1 rapidly decrease with the increase of frequency. From 60 kHz (for 4), 25 kHz (for 7), and 12 kHz (for 8) to higher frequencies, their ε1 remains nearly unchanged.

Luminescent Properties

Recently, luminescent Zn(II) and Cd(II) coordination compounds have been intensively investigated for their interesting fluorescence properties and potential applications as new luminescent materials. For example, some zinc complexes have been reported to be used as organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs). In this work, luminescence properties of all compounds have been explored at room temperature in the solid state. Consequently, all complexes exhibit photoluminescence properties in the solid state []. As illustrated in Figure S15a−h, the intense emission bands at 433 nm (λex = 328 nm) for 1, 435 nm (λex = 328 nm) for 2, 424 nm (λex = 324 nm) for 3, 460 nm (λex = 350 nm) for 4, 424 nm (λex = 324 nm) for 5, 406 nm (λex = 304 nm) for 6, 438 nm (λex = 324 nm) for 7 and 439 nm (λex = 330 nm) for 8 are observed. According to the reported literature, the free p-H2BDC, m-H2BDC, OH-m-H2BDC, H2OBA, and H2SDBA ligands do not emit any luminescence in the range of 400−800 nm. In order to understand the nature of the emission band of 5, the photoluminescence property of the free 5-But-m-H2BDC ligand was also analyzed. It exhibits an emission band at 317 nm upon excitation at 280 nm []. Taking the emission bands of these free organic ligands into consideration, the emission bands of 1−8 may be assigned as intraligand π → π* excited states for Cd(II) has a d10 configuration and cannot readily accept π-electron density. The relatively low emission energies when compared with the uncomplexed carboxylic acids arise from changes in their electronic structures due to deprotonation and coordination to the Lewis acidic Cd(II). These coordination polymers may be excellent candidates for potential photoactive materials because they are highly thermally stable.
cln_elements.clean_text:
The thermal stability of 1-8 was examined by TGA in a nitrogen atmosphere []. The TGA curve of 1 indicates that there is a weight loss of 6.01% from 30 to 180 °C, which can be attributed to the loss of a CH3OH molecule (calcd = 6.09%). The second weight-loss step of 7.80% from 180 to 388 °C can be assigned to the loss of a Me2NH molecule (calcd = 8.56%). The residual composition of 1 is then decomposed from 388 °C. The TGA curve of 2 exhibits three main steps of weight losses. The first step is from 30 to 169 °C corresponding to the loss of a lattice Me2NH molecule (obsd = 7.92%, calcd = 7.79%). The second weight loss region occurs over the range of 169-350 °C relevant to the release of two Me2NH molecules (obsd = 16.84%, calcd = 15.58%). Above 350 °C the framework of 2 is decomposed gradually. For 3, the TGA curve shows that the Me2NH molecules are lost from 30 to 116 °C (obsd = 8.85%, calcd = 9.12%), and from 116 °C the framework of 2 was gradually decomposed. The TGA curve of 4 reveals that three kinds of guest molecules are gradually released from 30 to 255 °C (obsd = 20.18%, calcd = 19.13%), the successive weight-loss step could be corresponding to the release of a Me2NH molecule (obsd = 6.54%, calcd = 7.0%). Compound 5 is stable up to 120 °C, from which to 336 °C the two coordinated DMF molecules are lost (obsd = 19.35%, calcd = 19.16%). From 336 °C the framework of 5 begins to collapse. As for 6, it is stable up to about 264 °C, from which to 287 °C occurs the first weight-loss step corresponding to the release of a Me2NH molecule (obsd = 6.92%, calcd = 6.64%). For 7, the TGA curve indicates that the DMF and CH3OH guest molecules are lost from 30 to 265 °C (obsd = 11.67%, calcd = 11.94%), while the subsequent weight-loss step which spans from 265 to 286 °C corresponds to the loss of a Me2NH molecule (obsd = 4.83%, calcd = 5.12%). For 8, the three coordinated water molecules are lost from 30 to 322 °C (obsd = 4.01%, calcd = 3.95%), and from 322 °C the framework of 8 decomposed quickly.

Ferroelectric Properties

Compounds 4, 7, and 8 crystallize in noncentrosymmetric space groups (Cc, Cc, and P3, respectively), whose corresponding point groups fall in the 10 polar point groups (C 1, C  s , C 2, C 2v , C 3, C 3v , C 4, C 4v , C 6, C 6v ) required for ferroelectric materials. Therefore, the ferroelectric properties of 4, 7, and 8 were examined. Experimental results indicate that they probably exhibit ferroelectric properties. Figure  clearly shows that there is an electric hysteresis loop in 4 that is a typical feature for ferroelectric material with a remanent polarization (Pr) of ca. 0.0069 μC cm-2 and coercive field (Ec) of ca. 335 V cm-1. The saturation spontaneous polarization (Ps) of 4 is ca. 0.016 μC cm-2. Similarly, both the P-E curves of 7 and 8 also display an electric hysteresis loop that is characteristic of a ferroelectric material (Figures  and ). The values of Pr, Ec and Ps can be estimated to be 0.0172 (for 7) and 0.0154 μC cm-2 (for 8), 592 (for 7) and 746 kV cm-1 (for 8) and 0.053 (for 7) and 0.041 μC cm-2 (for 8), respectively. We also studied the behavior of permittivity (ε) = ε1(ω) - iε 2(ω), where ε1(ω) and iε 2(ω) are the real (dielectric constant) and imaginary (dielectric loss) parts, respectively. As shown in , the respective frequency dependence of the dielectric constants ε1 of 4, 7, and 8 at room temperature (20 °C) indicate that their ε1 rapidly decrease with the increase of frequency. From 60 kHz (for 4), 25 kHz (for 7), and 12 kHz (for 8) to higher frequencies, their ε1 remains nearly unchanged.

Luminescent Properties

Recently, luminescent Zn(II) and Cd(II) coordination compounds have been intensively investigated for their interesting fluorescence properties and potential applications as new luminescent materials. For example, some zinc complexes have been reported to be used as organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs). In this work, luminescence properties of all compounds have been explored at room temperature in the solid state. Consequently, all complexes exhibit photoluminescence properties in the solid state []. As illustrated in Figure S15a-h, the intense emission bands at 433 nm (λex = 328 nm) for 1, 435 nm (λex = 328 nm) for 2, 424 nm (λex = 324 nm) for 3, 460 nm (λex = 350 nm) for 4, 424 nm (λex = 324 nm) for 5, 406 nm (λex = 304 nm) for 6, 438 nm (λex = 324 nm) for 7 and 439 nm (λex = 330 nm) for 8 are observed. According to the reported literature, the free p-H2BDC, m-H2BDC, OH-m-H2BDC, H2OBA, and H2SDBA ligands do not emit any luminescence in the range of 400-800 nm. In order to understand the nature of the emission band of 5, the photoluminescence property of the free 5-But-m-H2BDC ligand was also analyzed. It exhibits an emission band at 317 nm upon excitation at 280 nm []. Taking the emission bands of these free organic ligands into consideration, the emission bands of 1-8 may be assigned as intraligand π → π* excited states for Cd(II) has a d10 configuration and cannot readily accept π-electron density. The relatively low emission energies when compared with the uncomplexed carboxylic acids arise from changes in their electronic structures due to deprotonation and coordination to the Lewis acidic Cd(II). These coordination polymers may be excellent candidates for potential photoactive materials because they are highly thermally stable.
